questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with periorbital oedema and mild oliguria but no hypertension. Investigations reveal serum albumin <2.5 g/dL, serum creatinine 0.5 mg/dL, urine protein 3+, and no RBCs or casts in the urine. A renal biopsy was performed, and the histopathological findings are shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Presence of 3+ urine protein and hypoalbuminemia with oedema indicates a likely diagnosis of Nephrotic Syndrome.

  • Since there is no hematuria or hypertension, it is likely to beIdiopathic Nephrotic Syndrome, most commonly showing a histological pattern of Minimal Change Disease in a 2-8-year-old boy.
  • The disease is so named because the light microscopy shows minimal to no change. However, electron microscopy shows effacement of the foot processes of podocytes.
  • Oliguria is more characteristic of acute nephritic syndrome but can occasionally occur in nephrotic syndrome due to intravascular volume depletion from severe hypoalbuminemia, leading to reduced renal perfusion as oedema worsens.

questions.text: A child presents with dark-brown coloured urine for 3 days with mild oedema of face and legs with 2+ proteinuria. BP is 130/90, RBC Casts are present in the urine and serum cholesterol is 186 mg/dl. Which of the following does not present with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with dark-brown urine, mild oedema, hypertension, 2+ proteinuria, and RBC casts, indicating a nephritic syndrome rather than nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is characterised by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, oedema, and hyperlipidemia. The presence of hematuria and RBC casts makes nephrotic syndrome unlikely, as it typically lacks glomerular hematuria.

Diagnostic Criteria for Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • MPGN, as well as FSGS, can have such a presentation.
  • Likewise, IgA Nephropathycan also have a similar presentation, often triggered by a preceding infection in the last 1-7 days.

Reference:

  1. https://www.aafp.org/pubs/afp/issues/2016/0315/p479.html

questions.text: What is the time duration to define steroid resistance in childhood nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Failure to respond to daily, full-dose steroids for 6 week constitutes steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in children.

choices.text: More common in girls than boys

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Minimal Change Diseaseis a histopathological entity commonly seen in children with nephrotic syndrome.
  • The disease is so-named because thelight microscopy shows minimal to no change. However, electron microscopy shows effacement of the foot processes of podocytes.
  • MCD leads to excess albumin loss in urine, causing severe hypoalbuminemia and is thus theMC cause of childhood nephrotic syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

More common in girls than boys (Option A): Minimal change disease is more common in boys than girls.

Non-selective proteinuria (Option B): It causes selective proteinuria.

Cyclosporine is effective first-line therapy (Option D): Most cases respond well to Oral Prednisolone as the first line therapy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child developed periorbital puffiness following an acute febrile illness. His spot urine protein sample showed a protein: creatinine ratio of 3.5:1. There was no hypertension or hematuria. The child was started on oral prednisolone @ 2mg/kg/day as a single morning dose. Despite 9 days of therapy, the child continues to have periorbital oedema and a persistently elevated protein: creatinine ratio. What needs to be done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Childhood Nephrotic Syndrome:

  • Nephrotic syndrome in a child is said to be there when there is massive proteinuria (Urine protein excretion >40 mg/m2/hr or spot urine protein creatinine ratio is >2:1) with other features like hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia and hypercoagulability of blood
  • A child aged 2 to 6 years and presenting with only massive proteinuria and no hematuria/hypertension, is treated on the lines of minimal change disease. These children need no renal biopsy routinely and are started on oral prednisolone @ 2 mg/kg/day given for 6 weeks daily, followed by 5 mg/kg alternate day for 6 weeks
  • If a child does not respond to daily steroids for 6 weeks, he is called steroid-resistant and a renal biopsy is indicated.
  • Since the child in question has received steroids at full dose only for 9 days, we shall continue the same and wait for remission. If remission doesn't come or partially comes after6 weeks of steroid therapy, then we will refer to a pediatric nephrologist for considering steroid resistance and doing a renal biopsy.
  • Levamisole and cyclophosphamide are indicated in frequently relapsing and steroid-dependent varieties and hence not the answer here.

questions.text: On evaluation of a child referred in view of periorbital oedema, a urine dipstick examination was performed, and the dipstick showed urine protein of 3+. This value translates to how much ofthe urinary protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Urine dipstick examination for urinary protein is reported as

  • Negative: 0
  • Trace: 10-29 mg/dL
  • 1+: 30-100 mg/dL
  • 2+: 100-300 mg/dL
  • 3+: 300-1000 mg/dL
  • 4+: >1000 mg/dL

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with swelling that has increased over the past week. The swelling is most noticeable around his eyes in the mornings, but is most notable in his legs in the afternoon. On examination, he has pitting oedema of the bilateral lower extremities. He is also mildly hypertensive. Labs are significant for hypoalbuminemia and 3+ proteinuria. What is the most likely aetiology of the child's hypoalbuminemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's presentation is consistent with idiopathic nephrotic syndrome.

  • Nephrotic syndromeresults from urinary protein losses, which lead to hypoalbuminemia.
  • The hypoalbuminemia leads to dependent oedema. As such, the oedema may be most noticeable around the eyes in the mornings with a shift to the lower extremitiesas the day progresses.
  • Hypertension may occasionally be present.
  • Typical laboratory findingsinclude serum hypoalbuminemia, proteinuria, and hyperlipidemia.
  • Idiopathic nephrotic syndromeis the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in childhood.

choices.text: Hypertension is relatively uncommon compared to nephritic syndrome
Minimal change disease is common in children <10 years

questions.text: All are true regarding childhood nephrotic syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of low complement levels indicates complement-mediated injury, which is a feature of glomerulonephritis like PSGN, but is not seen in Nephrotic Syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Hypertension is relatively uncommon compared to nephritic syndrome (Option A): Hypertension can sometimes occur in Nephrotic syndrome, but is more commonly a feature of acute nephritic syndrome.

Minimal change disease is common in children <10 years (Option B): Minimal Change Disease tends to occur in aged 2-8 years.

Massive proteinuria is often seen (Option C): Massive proteinuria is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with generalised oedema. On investigation, his serum cholesterol level was 238 mg/dl, urine protein was 3+ and stool microscopy revealed oval fat bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nephrotic range proteinuria is defined as proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hour or a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

  • The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome arising from the large urinary losses of protein is hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), oedema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL).

choices.text: Oedema that improves throughout the day

questions.text: You are teaching a group of medical students the differential diagnosis of oedema in children. You take them to the bedside of a patient who has oedema associated with hypoproteinemia secondary to proteinuria. Of the following, the feature you are MOST likely to observe in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nephrotic syndrome usually presents with oedema that is periorbital and more prominent early in the morning and with minimal systemic symptoms.

  • Oedema is the most easily identified clinical feature associated with hypoproteinemia.
  • Impaired cardiac function leads to worsening peripheral oedema as the day progresses and is associated with exertion and increased activity.
  • Pitting oedema is not pathognomonicfor any specific underlying aetiology.

Explanation:

Mutations in the NPHS-1 gene produce an Autosomal Recessive type of Congenital Nephrotic Syndrome called as "Finnish Type". NPHS-1 codes for nephrin protein, a key component of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: Which among the following is the drug of choice in Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus or cyclosporine) are the first-line treatment for steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) after failure to achieve remission with 4 weeks of corticosteroids.

Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome (SRNS):

  • Failure to achieve remission after 4 weeks of corticosteroids.
  • Common causes:
    • FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis)
    • MCNS (Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome)
    • Membranoproliferative GN
    • Genetic mutations
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (CNI): Cyclosporine, Tacrolimus
    • Indication: First-line for SRNS.
    • Side effects: Hypertension, nephrotoxicity, hirsutism, gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: Most important mechanism of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Earlier, we used to follow the underfill hypothesis, which stated that hypoalbuminemia produces a fall in oncotic pressure and causes oedema.
  • Now, we know that although hypoalbuminemia is an initiating cause, the actual cause for most clinical oedema is primary Na+/H2O retention, the so-called Overfill Hypothesis.
  • The overfill hypothesispostulates that nephrotic syndrome is associated with primary sodium retention, with subsequent volume expansion and leakage of excess fluid into the interstitium.
  • There is accumulating evidence that theepithelial sodium channel in the distal tubule may play a key role in sodium reabsorption in nephrotic syndrome.
  • The clinical weaknesses of this hypothesis are evidenced by the numerous nephrotic patients who present with an obvious clinical picture of intravascular volume depletion: low blood pressure, tachycardia, and elevated hemoconcentration.
  • Furthermore, amiloride, an epithelial sodium channel blocker, used alone is not sufficient to induce adequate diuresis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with deafness and recurrent hematuria. Investigations suggest chronic kidney disease. Family history reveals that the maternal uncle died of a similar illness. Kidney biopsy shows minimal changes on light microscopy, but electron microscopy reveals glomerular basement membrane abnormalities. Which of the following statements about the likely diagnosis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of hematuria, CKD, sensorineural hearing loss, and a maternal uncle with similar illness strongly points toward X-linked Alport Syndrome. Posterior lenticonus is not characteristic of Alport syndrome; the pathognomonic ocular finding is anterior lenticonus.

Alport Syndrome:

  • Hereditary nephritis due to mutations in type IV collagen genes.
  • Affects glomerular, cochlear, and ocular basement membranes.
  • Genetic types:
    • X-linked (70-80%): Mutation in COL4A5 (α5 chain). (Option A)
    • Autosomal recessive (~5%): Mutations in COL4A3 and COL4A4 (α3, α4 chains).
    • Autosomal dominant (~19-31%): COL4A3-COL4A4 locus mutations.
    • X-linked AS + leiomyomatosis: Contiguous mutation in COL4A5 and COL4A6.
  • Pathology:
    • Early (1st decade): Minimal findings on light microscopy. (Option D)
    • Progressive changes:
      • Mesangial proliferation, capillary wall thickening, and glomerulosclerosis.
      • Tubular atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and foam cells.
    • Electron microscopy:
      • Thickening, thinning, splitting, and layering of GBM.
      • May show uniform thinning or be normal in some.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hematuria:
      • Microscopic hematuria = most common initial sign.
      • Gross hematuria in ~50%, often post-URI.
    • Proteinuria:
      • Mild/absent in females, progressive and nephrotic-range in males.
    • Sensorineural hearing loss:
      • Seen in 90% of hemizygous males, 67% AR, and 20% heterozygous females.
      • High-frequency loss, progressive → affects speech. (Option B)
    • Ocular abnormalities (30-40%):
      • Anterior lenticonus (pathognomonic). (Option C)
      • Macular flecks, recurrent corneal erosions.
    • Rare: Leiomyomatosis of oesophagus, trachea, and female genitals.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has been presenting with cola-colored urine for the past day. Four weeks ago, he had a mild sore throat without fever. On examination, he has normal growth parameters, respiratory rate of 18/min, heart rate of 94/min, and blood pressure of 138/90 mm Hg. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows specific gravity 1.015, pH 5.5, 3+ blood, 2+ leukocyte esterase, and no protein or nitrites. Which of the following tests is MOST likely to provide both diagnostic and prognostic information about his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A school-going aged boy having a sore throat, followed by cola-coloured urine suggesting hematuria, hypertension in 1-4 weeks, suggests a likely diagnosis of Acute Glomerulonephritis caused by Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis. Low C3 supports the diagnosis of post-streptococcal GN, and normalisation over time correlates with recovery, offering both diagnostic and prognostic value.

  • Acute glomerulonephritisis characterised by the triad of cola-colored urine, hypertension, and azotemia on serum chemistry. These patients may or may not have proteinuria with or without hypoalbuminemia.
  • Patients with nephritis may have hypocomplementemic (associated with a low C3) or normocomplementemic (associated with a normal C3) glomerulonephritis.
  • Serum complement evaluation is important for characterising patients with acute nephritis.
  • A low C3 is an important clue for diagnosis and also has prognostic significance in PSGN.
  • Hypocomplementemia usually resolves within 8 weeks in postinfectious GN (PIGN).
  • Persistently low C3 level is associated with an increased risk for membranoproliferative GN and possibly a poorer prognosis.

Explanation of other options:

Antistreptolysin O titres (Option A) can confirm recent streptococcal infection, but do not assess disease severity or prognosis of glomerulonephritis.

Renal ultrasonography (Option C) is useful for detecting structural renal anomalies but not helpful in diagnosing or monitoring post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

Urine microscopy (Option D) may show RBC casts, confirming the glomerular origin of hematuria, but offers no prognostic value like complement levels do.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presented with a boil on the leg 2 weeks ago and is now presenting with cola coloured urine, 2+ urinary protein, facial oedema and has a BP of 120/80 mm Hg. There is no other symptom or rash. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A school-going-aged boy developing acute nephritic syndrome 2 weeks after a boil (pyoderma) indicates a likely diagnosis of Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis.

Explanation of other options:

Minimal Change Disease (Option A) usually does not have gross hematuria & tends to have massive proteinuria (3+ or 4+)

IgA Nephropathy (Option B) presents with acute nephritic syndrome within 2-6 days of preceding sore throat or pyoderma, not 2 weeks after.

HSP nephritis (Option D) will also have palpable purpura, joint involvement with GIT manifestations and since these are not mentioned, unlikely to be the answer here.
